renovationScope: Comprehensive - Full adaptive reuse of 1930s industrial warehouse building
circularElements: SENAB supplied refurbished office furniture adapted for hotel use
Vintage and second-hand furniture integrated throughout
Original concrete floors polished and exposed
Original steel structural elements visible in design

quantifiedImpact.co2Reduction: 60-80% embodied carbon reduction vs. new build

marketImpact.awardsRecognition: World Architecture Festival 2017, Swedish Steel Prize 2017
marketImpact.industryInfluence: Referenced in 50+ sustainability case studies globally

whatWorked: Adaptive reuse dramatically reduced costs AND carbon - €120M savings made business case compelling
Industrial aesthetic celebrated - Original warehouse character became design feature
Early quantification - Sweco's CO2 analysis provided clear data for decision-making
LEED + Swan dual certification demonstrated both international and Nordic standards compliance
challenges: Fire safety compliance for historic structure required documentation and upgrades
Sourcing timeline uncertainty - Salvaged materials availability less predictable
Material documentation - Creating equivalency documentation for reused elements

replicability.chainPotential: Medium-High - Nobis operates 5+ hotels, model can replicate across portfolio
replicability.economicViability: Proven - 30% construction cost savings, premium pricing maintained

fyraActions: Contact hotel GM for site visit and operational lessons
Contact Amanda Borneke (Sweco) to explore partnership

renovationScope: Adaptive Reuse - Military barracks → boutique hotel
circularElements: Original wooden floors restored where possible
Historic window frames repaired and reused
Antique and vintage furniture throughout (curated mix)
Mid-century Swedish design pieces sourced second-hand
Design-for-disassembly approach due to heritage restrictions

quantifiedImpact.co2Reduction: Estimated 70-80% embodied carbon savings (typical for 18th-century adaptive reuse)

whatWorked: Heritage restrictions = automatic circularity - Preservation mandate ensured minimal waste
Historic character = market differentiator - Uniqueness commands premium
Reversible design allows future flexibility
Cultural tourism appeal - History story enhances guest experience
challenges: Heritage compliance complexity - Every change requires Riksantikvarieämbetet approval
Higher renovation costs - Skilled heritage craftsmen more expensive
Limited modern amenities - Historic structure constrains elevators, electrical capacity
Heritage permits can add 3-6 months to project schedule

replicability.chainPotential: Low-Medium - Each building unique, cannot standardize
replicability.economicViability: ★★★★ High for boutique operators - Premium pricing justified by uniqueness

fyraActions: Site visit to study how modern hospitality functions work in historic structure
Contact Joachim Olausson for operational lessons and guest response
Review heritage compliance process (useful for future adaptive reuse projects)

renovationScope: Comprehensive renovation - 1970s office building → lifestyle hotel
circularElements: Vintage furniture integrated throughout public spaces
Upcycled wood panels from Swedish forests (salvaged timber)
Reclaimed materials in accent walls and decorative features

quantifiedImpact.co2Reduction: Estimated 50-70% embodied carbon savings vs. new build
quantifiedImpact.chainWideImpact: 280+ Scandic properties apply similar circular practices

financialBreakdown.additionalCosts: €65k (late documentation, fire testing delays, contractor change orders)

operationalPerformance.lifestyleBrandAppeal: Strong millennial/Gen Z appeal despite limited circular achievement

rootCauses: Late circular engagement: Sustainability consultant hired AFTER design 50% complete = structural decisions locked
Prescriptive specifications: Architect specified exact furniture models before circular assessment = no flexibility
Contractor unfamiliarity: Traditional contractor with no circular experience = risk-averse approach
Supply chain timing: Discovered YLLW Factory 18-week lead time AFTER schedule finalized = timeline conflict
Documentation gap: Supplier provided basic invoices, building authority required Material Passports = 8-week delay
Budget miss: Fire certification €45k not budgeted = value engineering cut reused items

financialImpact.budgetReallocation: €2.12M went to new furniture (defaulted to original specs)
financialImpact.missedCertificationCredits: LEED 4 material credits lost (would have enabled Platinum vs. Gold)

lessonsForIndustry: Engage circular consultant in PRE-DESIGN phase (feasibility study, not construction documents)
Use PERFORMANCE-BASED specifications (functional requirements) not PRESCRIPTIVE (exact models)
Pre-qualify circular suppliers BEFORE tendering (verify lead times, documentation capability)
Budget for fire testing and documentation from DAY ONE (€50-80k typical for 100+ room hotel)
Select contractor with circular experience OR include circular training in contract (2-day workshop minimum)
Add +4 week circular buffer to schedule (16-20 week lead time vs. 12 week new furniture standard)

whatWorked: Chain-wide circular practices create economies of scale
LEED Gold certification in Sweden demonstrates international standards compliance
Furniture rental model allows upgrades without waste
Large property size (494 rooms) shows circularity works at scale
challenges: Specific supplier/material details limited in public documentation
Project-specific environmental data not separated from chain-wide reporting

replicability.chainPotential: Very High - Scandic has 280+ properties for replication
replicability.economicViability: Proven - LEED Gold achieved at large scale

fyraActions: Contact Isabelle Blomqvist to discuss Scandic's circular renovation standards
Study Stylt Trampoli's approach to lifestyle hotel sustainability integration
Explore partnership opportunities for Scandic's ongoing renovations

circularElements: Reclaimed wood paneling from Swedish industrial buildings
Upcycled leather furniture (old leather goods deconstructed and reformed)
Vintage lighting fixtures restored and rewired
Reclaimed bricks used as decorative elements
Salvaged doors repurposed as wall art/headboards
Mix of vintage Swedish design (second-hand) and new sustainable pieces
Upcycled upholstery (leather from car seats, industrial textiles)
Custom-made from waste streams (tables from reclaimed wood)

quantifiedImpact.qualitativeImpact: Material reuse reduced manufacturing emissions (not quantified)
quantifiedImpact.designValue: Urban vagabond aesthetic - celebrating imperfection and patina

whatWorked: Upcycled materials create unique design story without formal certifications

International designer (Studio Aisslinger) brings global expertise
Design storytelling trumps certification for boutique positioning
challenges: No quantified environmental data limits ROI communication
Custom fabrication can be labor-intensive vs. standard procurement
Supplier details not public - harder to replicate sourcing approach

replicability.chainPotential: Low - Custom approach hard to standardize
replicability.economicViability: Medium - Upcycled materials save on procurement but require design expertise

fyraActions: Site visit to study Studio Aisslinger's material integration approach

renovationScope: System-Level Circular Design - New concept built on circular economy principles
circularElements: Design-for-Disassembly: Modular furniture for easy disassembly
Click-together systems (no glue/permanent fasteners where possible)
Mono-materials preferred (easier to recycle at end-of-life)
Material passports for all major furnishings
Designed for refurbishment with spare parts inventory

quantifiedImpact.designTarget: 50% embodied carbon reduction vs. conventional budget hotel
quantifiedImpact.materialReuseEnabling: Design-for-disassembly enables future reuse at end-of-life (15-20 years)
quantifiedImpact.lifecycleCost: Cost-neutral or slightly higher upfront, but lifecycle cost savings significant

financialBreakdown.designPremium: €450 per room (3.6% premium for DfD design vs. conventional)
financialBreakdown.materialPassportCost: €28k total (€102 per room - digital documentation system)
financialBreakdown.futureResaleValue: €4,200 per room estimated (components designed for 2nd-life market)

operationalPerformance.corporateESG: 22 corporate contracts signed (companies valuing circular procurement)

designForDisassemblyDetails.clickFurniture: 87% of furniture uses click-together assembly (no glue, reversible)
designForDisassemblyDetails.standardizedComponents: 42 component types across all rooms (vs. 180 unique parts conventional)
designForDisassemblyDetails.materialPassports: Digital passports for 2,400 components (QR codes for maintenance/resale)
designForDisassemblyDetails.takeBackAgreements: 6 suppliers with binding take-back contracts (furniture, textiles, carpet)
designForDisassemblyDetails.sparePartsInventory: €45k spare parts stock (enables 10+ year maintenance without new procurement)
designForDisassemblyDetails.repairability: Average repair time: 12 minutes per component (vs. 45 min conventional = 75% faster)

replicabilityFramework.scandicRollout: Planned: 15 Scandic GO properties by 2028 (3-4 per year)
replicabilityFramework.designStandardization: GO design manual: 280-page spec (enables rapid replication)
replicabilityFramework.costCurveProjection: Property 5+: Zero premium (economies of scale eliminate DfD cost)
replicabilityFramework.trainingProgram: Scandic GO Academy: 2-day DfD training for contractors (40 trained to date)

whatWorked: First hotel concept designed specifically for circular economy from ground up
Design-for-disassembly enables true end-of-life material recovery
Material passports create transparency for future renovations
Budget segment shows circularity isn't just for luxury hotels
Standardization across chain enables economies of scale
challenges: Too new for performance data (opened October 2024)
Supplier details not publicly disclosed
Circular design requires supplier collaboration on take-back agreements

replicability.chainPotential: ★★★★★ Exceptional - Designed explicitly for chain replication
replicability.economicViability: Designed for cost-neutrality with lifecycle savings

fyraActions: Contact Isabelle Blomqvist for Scandic GO supplier requirements and design standards
Study modular design approach for future Fyra budget hotel projects
Request material passport documentation as model for Fyra projects

Unique model: Museum gets storage solution + educational reach
Hotel gets unique, high-quality furniture at low/no cost
Cultural tourism: Guests sleep in 'museum annexes'

quantifiedImpact.co2Saved: 5.7 tonnes CO2e saved through furniture reuse vs. purchasing new
quantifiedImpact.culturalImpact: Educational guest exposure to historic Swedish furniture

whatWorked: Museum partnership creates win-win: Museum solves storage, hotel gets unique furniture
Low-cost circular model (minimal furniture acquisition spending)
Cultural storytelling adds marketing differentiation
5.7 tonnes CO2 saved demonstrates small-scale circular impact
Partnership model replicable with other museums/cultural institutions
challenges: Small scale (34 rooms) limits scalability
Requires proximity to museum with suitable collection
Furniture rotation may complicate procurement consistency

renovationScope: Comprehensive - Climate-positive design (Most intensive circular hotel in Nordics)
circularElements: 43% of interiors from recycled/upcycled sources (2021 wing)
17% climate-positive (removes more CO2 than emitted in construction)
Upcycled construction waste → furniture (offcut wood pressed into furniture)
Surplus bricks crushed → decorative Earth plaster walls
Material passports for all major elements
Living lab (hotel tests circular innovations for industry)

quantifiedImpact.climatePositive: 17% climate-positive (2021 wing) - sequesters more CO2 than construction emitted

financialBreakdown.circularPremium: €180k (2.2% premium for circular materials vs. conventional)
financialBreakdown.5YearROI: €425k - Circular premium paid back in 5 years through lab revenue alone

operationalPerformance.sustainabilityTourists: 68% of guests cite sustainability as booking factor

circularMaterialsDetailed.graniteTerrazzo: 12 tonnes quarry waste → bathroom surfaces (€45k savings vs. imported stone)
circularMaterialsDetailed.brickPlaster: 8 tonnes surplus bricks crushed → decorative walls (€18k savings, zero waste)
circularMaterialsDetailed.CLToffcuts: Construction waste wood pressed → furniture (23 chairs, 8 tables - €12k savings)
circularMaterialsDetailed.textileWaste: Upchair seating (45 chairs from textile waste) - €28k vs. €41k new equivalent
circularMaterialsDetailed.carpetTakeback: Interface carpet tiles with take-back guarantee (circular economy closed loop)

carbonAccountingDetail.carbonSequestration: 290 tonnes CO2e (CLT timber storage over 60-year lifespan)
carbonAccountingDetail.totalAvoidance: 562 tonnes CO2e avoided (290 stored + 272 construction reduction)

renovationScope: Adaptive reuse - 1910s Arts & Crafts townhouse converted to luxury boutique hotel with vintage/antique furniture approach (2010-2012)

60-70% of furniture vintage/antique (~200-250 vintage furniture pieces)

Premium textiles and finishes designed for 20-30 year lifespan
Timeless design approach (won't look dated in 10 years)
High-quality antiques chosen for longevity and repairability

quantifiedImpact.co2SavingsEstimated: 15-35 tonnes CO2e avoided through vintage furniture vs. new (rough estimate based on ~200-250 pieces)

whatWorked: Residential authenticity - Vintage furniture reinforces 'home' feeling
Guest loyalty - ~40% repeat guest rate (very high for luxury)
Timeless design - Won't need major refresh for decades
Premium pricing justified - Uniqueness commands €600-1,500/night
Ilse Crawford reputation - Designer elevated profile
challenges: Small scale - 12 rooms not representative of typical hotel projects
Sourcing complexity - Curating 200+ unique vintage pieces time-intensive
Cost - High-end antiques can exceed new luxury furniture costs
Standardization impossible - Cannot replicate this approach at scale
Maintenance skills - Antique furniture requires specialized care

replicability.scalability: ★ VERY LOW - Highly curated, boutique one-off requiring specialized curator (12 rooms, time-intensive sourcing of 200+ antiques). BUT: PRINCIPLES replicable (quality, longevity, timelessness)
replicability.chainPotential: VERY LOW - Antithesis of chain standardization, each property would be unique. BUT: Small Luxury Hotels of the World collection model possible
replicability.economicViability: ★★★★ HIGH for small luxury - Premium pricing (€600-1,500/night) sustained, high occupancy, strong ROI (higher upfront cost offset by longevity and pricing power). BUT: Requires significant capital and expertise
